title: Red Herring
description: Diverting attention from a real issue by focusing on a topic with only a surface relevance to the original.
examples:
Jack: “Bob Dylan was the greatest songwriter.”
Jill: “No, Fleetwood Mac had the greatest live performers of all time”
Why are you upset? Think of all the starving children around the world who have it worse than you.
explanation:
When subtlety isn’t an option, a red herring may be employed to confuse the audience. By pivoting to an entirely unrelated, outrageous, and highly charged topic, a speaker can make the audience forget the original discussion.
Some red herrings will subtly switch contexts, retaining superficial similarity between the new and original topic to minimize people’s ability to detect a context switch.
actions: Be skeptical when someone responds to a controversial question by calling attention to another charged or polarized topic without actually answering the original question.
Ask yourself: Does this answer the question? Red herrings are meant to distract from the original topic; it could be worth re-asking the question.
